Upgrade to the latest FishEye and Crucible release

fields.description:
The upgrade system doesn't take into account if the application has been setup yet.  You therefore currently get an error when you're setting up JIRA with an empty database, as the defaultDashboard is null when JIRA hasn't been set up yet.  This breaks the first upgrade task, which generates an error in the logs, and requires a JIRA restart for all the upgrade tasks to run successfully.

We need to detect if the underlying application has been setup (probably something to add to SAAL) and make sure the upgradeManager uses this information.
fields.summary: Plugin upgradeManager should only run if the application has been setup.

fields.description: Currently, the external SVN URL that users access to get to the SVN repository is somewhat hacked in.  We basically look at JIRA's baseURL and add 'svn' to the end.  If future, users may want to provide their own SVN repositories, which will require a better way working out the remote URL.  The SVN application info should probably provide an 'internal' and 'external' url.
fields.summary: Provide support for external SVN repositories

fields.description:
From Jeff Turner:

I think we'll have lots of customers claiming that creating issues/comments from email is a core feature
(http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/issue_creation_email.html).

Which is unfortunate as non-super-sysadmins can't define POP servers, nor define listeners to handle them.

Perhaps we can ask Contegix to:
 - create a jira@<hosteddomain> mailbox for every deployment
 - set jira@<hosteddomain> to be the default mail server From address.
 - have a single Comment handler service configured by default

That way, customers get commenting by email, but not issue creation by email. It keeps 80% of people happy with little extra work.
fields.summary: Support comment creation from email

fields.description:
- Go to JIRA Studio project and click on "Source" tab
- You should see commits for the project
- Click on crucible icon next to the changeset
- It will bring you to the screen where you choose Crucible project for your new review.
I think that screen should be skipped and new reviews should be automatically created in associated Crucible project.
fields.summary: Creating crucible review from fisheye should automatically create review in associated crucible project

fields.description:
From user:
On submitting ('Save' action) a page edit in the Wiki, we occasionally get an error in Internet Explorer: <>
Running IE 6.0 SP1 under Citrix metaframe client
This does not seem to be related to the edit view (wysiwyg, wikitags, preview)
The path I took: click on my dashboard shortcut (automatically log on), Tab Wiki, browse to lemma, tab 'edit'
I usually switch between rich text. wikitags and preview views before saving.
Sometimes when saving, the browser crashes. I'll try to make the 'sometimes' more specific for you in the next few days!
fields.summary: Save wiki page crashes IE

fields.description:
Contegix has a list of changes they'd like to see for the fireball.  

1. Add a version to the fireball name.
2. Unzip directory should either be static *OR* match the name of the
fireball.  We are perfectly fine with either one as long as it remains
consistent.
3. Ensure crowd.properties files for the applications contain the
correct passwords as imported in the initial-data.xml.
4. Add ajp port to crowd.properties file for FE.  Below is the snippet
current being used.  You can decide how to address the bind location.
We left our default (j2ee.instance.jirastudio.com-fisheye:8009) in.
    <web-server context="source">
        <http bind=":3990"/>
        <ajp13 bind="j2ee.instance.jirastudio.com-fisheye:8009"/>
    </web-server>


  Some of these were previously mentioned in email, IMs, etc., but
this makes it "real".


  The next issue will be tackling the upgrades.  For that, we would
like the following:
1. List of changes to any configuration files or how to address it.
For example, if FE/Cruc config.xml changes, will it re-add the
repositories to it?
2. Ensure the crowd.properties files are correct for the password.  If
the password in there needs to change, we need some way of updating
the database.  (See #3 to explain.)
3. List of any changes to the initial-data imports.  We reverse
engineered this to automate installs.  Thus, if these change in *any*
manner, we need to redo it.  (This is *NOT* a complaint about having
to redo it, just being mentioned as it takes time.)
fields.summary: Make fireball changes for Contegix
